item.title: The End of Gratipay
item.dc:creator: Chad Whitacre
item.content:encoded:
Gratipay is shutting down at the end of theÂ year

Update: Gratipay is dead. Long live Liberapay!

On May 11, 2012, I was sitting in a coffee shop wishing I could work full-time on my open source projects. A lightbulb went off, and three weeks later I launched Gittip, a â€œtip jar for GitHubâ€ (renamed two yearsÂ later).

The years since have seen all kinds of twists and turns, highs and lows. From an initial constituency of open source developers, our user base expanded to include tech diversity activists. The combination fueled exciting growth, until personality clashes boiled over into the Gittip Crisis. From there, provocateurs continued to take advantage of Gratipayâ€™s overly welcoming nature, until we had to admit that yes, online communities really do require moderation.

As luck would have it, we issued our first two user bans right as our close partner Balanced Payments went out of business. That quickly escalated into the Gratipocalypse, resulting in Gratipay 2.0 and a fork, Liberapay. Gratipay has continued to process payments in the two and a half years since, but at a much-reduced level.

Meanwhile, the problem of funding people to work full time on their open source projects has only gained greater urgency. Heartbleed led to headlines and the creation of the Core Infrastructure Initiative. Last yearâ€™s Roads and Bridges report led to this yearâ€™s Sustain conference.

At Gratipay weâ€™ve spent the past year gearing up to relaunch with a renewed focus on open source. However, funding open source is almost entirely about marketing, and we spent most of the past year writing code instead. File this one under, â€œopen source needs all the skill sets,â€ but also, â€œstartups need all the skillÂ sets.â€

And now weâ€™re out ofÂ runway.

We intend to continue processing existing weekly payments through the end of the year, which puts the last weekly payment cycle on December 28,Â 2017.

If you are currently receiving payments through Gratipay, thank you for your patronage. Iâ€™m sorry for the inconvenience of shutting down, for the loss of income this represents for you. Iâ€™m sorry that we couldnâ€™t make this work. Fortunately, there are great alternatives in the market now, such as Patreon, Liberapay, and Open Collective. If we can do anything to help you move to another platform, please get inÂ touch.

On December 29, 2017, we plan to switch gratipay.com to a static web page. Since it will likely take years to dispose of unclaimed balances in the proper legal way, it may be a while before we can fully delete our database.

Iâ€™m proud of and humbled by what the Gratipay community has accomplished over the past five and a half years. We moved $1.1 million from dozens of companies to hundreds of open source projects. We pioneered what it means to be an open organization. We tasted the future of work, even if Gratipay wonâ€™t be how we get there. We conducted a valuable experiment in cultivating an economy of gratitude, generosity, andÂ love.

Iâ€™m sorry for the mistakes I made. Iâ€™m grateful for all of you, and I wish you all theÂ best.

Thank you.

item.title: Your Company Should Probably Pay $2,000 per Person for Open Source
item.dc:creator: Chad Whitacre
item.content:encoded:
The volunteer open source community creates tremendous value for the global economy but gets almost nothing in return. Yes, by definition, open source software â€œshall not require a royalty or other fee.â€ But society needs the open source community to at least be financially solvent, and itâ€™s not. Itâ€™s barely surviving.

How can the open source community keep the lightsÂ on?

The answer is simple: companies need to pay for open source. They benefit the most from the communityâ€™s efforts, and they have the most money. Companies do already pay for about half of open source overall, by allowing their employees to work on open source software on company time. They also need to pay for the other half, the half produced by the volunteer open source community.

How much should companies pay?

Open sourceâ€™s royalty-free licensing is a primary reason for using open source in the first place, so we know that companies are not going to foot a trillion dollar bill. Luckily, they donâ€™t have to. Companies pay a premium for the right to direct an employeeâ€™s work. By giving up direct control over how the open source community spends its effort, they can realize a significant cost savings. The current discount of 99.98% is too extreme, but companies should be able to pay for the open source communityâ€™s labor at a significant discount, while the folks in the community make a modest living working in self-directed collaboration free of employment relationships. It feels like we should be able to make thisÂ work.

One way I like to think about the open source community is as an invisible tech giant. MÃ¥rten Mickos, CEO of HackerOne and former CEO of MySQL, puts the size of the open source community at about 500,000 people. Since Evan You and approximately three other people are the only ones currently living in a glorious open source future, letâ€™s put the full-time equivalency of those 500,000 people at 5%: that comes out to 25,000 engineers, which is about how many Alphabet has (per SEC filings). A big theme in open source sustainability is valuing non-code contributions: Alphabet employs about 50,000 non-engineers.

So if the open source community is a tech giant roughly the size of Alphabet, how much income does it need in order to sustainÂ itself?

Alphabetâ€™s revenue is $90B/yr, and their average compensation per person is $187,500/yr ($125,000/yr salary Ã— 1.5 for benefits). Now, researchers Daniel Kahnemann and Angus Deaton put the threshold of minimum compensation for maximum emotional well-being in the U.S. at $75,000/yr. Adjusting for inflation, letâ€™s eyeball it that Alphabet pays a 100% markup to direct their employeesâ€™ labor. In other words, we could rouse a slumbering open source giantâ€”and secure the future of the open source community we all rely onâ€”forÂ $45B/yr.

How much should each companyÂ pay?

Companies benefit from open source most directly in their own technical employeesâ€™ boosted productivity. There are 21M employed programmers in the world. To move 25,000 of them into full-time open source work (at a 50% cost savings) and also account for non-technical contributors, each company with their own technical employees should pay the open source community $2,143 per year per technical employee at theÂ company.

This would work out to maybe 1â€“3% of total employee compensation across a range of cases, which seems fair given that open source boosts productivity byÂ 20%.

How much should your companyÂ pay?

At Gratipay, we believe that companies want to pay for open source, and will pay for open source if itâ€™s easy enoughâ€”bureaucratically, technically, and socially.

Hopefully this post makes it a little easier by helping you decide how much to pay. If you are responsible for your companyâ€™s relationship with the open source community, please take it as a starting point for your own internal conversation about how much to pay for open source thisÂ year.

And once you decide, you can pay for open source on Gratipay.

Chad Whitacre is the founder of Gratipay, a startup that helps companies and others pay for open source. His roots are in the Python community. Email him of find him in Slack if you want to chat about how much to pay for open source, and how to make the case inside yourÂ company.

item.title: Open Source Captures 0.02% of the Value it Creates
item.dc:creator: Chad Whitacre
item.content:encoded:
Open Source Captures 0.02% of the Value it Creates, Leaving $852B/yr on theÂ Table

Two months ago, 100 folks gathered for Sustain, a one-day conversation about open source sustainability (Gratipay was a co-organizer). We talked about more than money, but money was definitely on the table. One of the questions left lingering in my mind, though, was how muchÂ money?

How much value is the open source community leaving on theÂ table?

My understanding from the #sustain channel in the Changelog Slack is that the Ford and Sloan foundations are funding research to answer this very question. In the mean time, letâ€™s break out a pencil and napkin, shallÂ we?

How large is the global economy? The techÂ sector?

The global economy is nominally $78T/yr, and tech accounts for $3T (4%) of that. Since only 78% of companies use open source, letâ€™s mark those down to $60.8T and $2.3T respectively.

How much value does open sourceÂ create?

Open source increases the value of tech companies by something like 21%, so letâ€™s call that $475B of annual value created by open source in tech ($2.3T Ã— 21%). Non-tech companies also use lots of software; letâ€™s estimate that open source accounts for 2.1% of their value. Thatâ€™s another $1.2T (($60.8Tâ€Šâ€”â€Š$2.3T) Ã— 2.1%). Open source creates $1.7T/yr ofÂ value.

How much value does the open source community create?

Companies produce half of open source software. The global community of open source volunteers produces the rest, thereby adding $853B of value to the global economy eachÂ year.

How much value does the open source community capture?

Surveying a list of open source foundations, IÂ see:

  • three with annual revenues above $10M (Linux Foundation and subsidiaries at $90M, Wikimedia at $65M, Mozillaâ€™s non-advertising revenue atÂ $12M),
  • maybe a dozen clocking in at around $1M (SFC, FSF, PSF),Â and
  • maybe 100 with annual budgets averaging $100,000 (DSF,Â OSI).

Rounding up, the total value captured by the open source community is maybe $200M/yr. Therefore, the open source community captures 0.02% of the value it creates. Conversely, it leaves 99.98% of the value it creates on the table, or about $852B perÂ year.

Our goal at Gratipay is to help the open source community capture more of the value it creates, by making it both socially and technically easy for your company to pay for open source. For example, we recently integrated npm so you can pay for your package.json.

Do you advocate for open source sustainability within your company? Drop me a line in email or Slack, Iâ€™d love to chat about working with you to pay openÂ source!

Follow-up

Your Company Should Probably Pay $2,000 per Person for Open Source

P.S. Donâ€™t trust my assumptions? Copy this Sheet to fiddle the knobs (the list of FLOSS foundations is in a secondÂ tab):

Open Source is Leaving $____ on the Table

On this model the uncaptured value comes out somewhere between $100B and $1T/yr. Even if captured value is off by an order of magnitude, the ratio still comes out to about 2% at bestâ€”lots of room for improvement.

item.title: Pay for your package.json

Today we shipped two further improvements:

  1. Upload a package.json to discover packages to give to. This helps you maximize the reach and effectiveness of your open source support, by narrowly targeting the long tail of open source you actuallyÂ use.
  2. The 48% of npm package maintainers who maintain more than one package (7% have 10+) can now apply for all those packages atÂ once.

Check out both at https://gratipay.com/on/npm/, and let us know how it goes via private email or public GitHub orÂ Twitter.

item.title: Integrating npm
item.dc:creator: Chad Whitacre
item.content:encoded:
Towards funding the long tail of openÂ source

Gratipay is on a quest to help companies fund the long tail of open source. Without funding, our digital infrastructure crumbles. Heartbleed is the headline, and led to the creation of the Core Infrastructure Initiative (CII). Three years later, OpenSSL and other projects are stronger, and we are all safer, thanks to the support the industry has shown throughÂ CII.

That said, CII only funded 14 projects last year. Libraries.io lists millions of open source packages, and only covers language ecosystems (no apt or yum). While todayâ€™s status quo works well for headline projects, it does not reach the long tail, where most of open source lives. We need all of open source to be healthy, from Linux to left-pad.

We have more work toÂ do.

At Gratipay, we think the answer to the problem of funding the long tail of open source is both social and technical. Today, we are taking a technical step forward by integrating the npm package manager directly into Gratipay. In its metadata, npm provides an email address for each package maintainer. Using this email, weâ€™ve made it a little bit easier for package maintainers to apply to use Gratipay to receive funding for theirÂ project.

This integration also paves the way for future improvements. Of course, we would like to integrate additional package managers. But the real innovation weâ€™re pursuing is aggregation, because we think thatâ€™s going to be important for reaching the long tail. Potential features along the wayÂ include:

  • pledging to projects that havenâ€™t signed upÂ yet,
  • claiming many packages at once,Â and
  • funding all of the projects in your package.json.

We are also doing a lot of thinking about the social component of helping companies fund the long tail of open source. Stay tuned on that, and join us at the Sustain conference next month to be part of the conversation.

Until then, we invite you to search for your npm packages on Gratipay and apply to join, so that you can receive funding for your open sourceÂ work!

item.title: Sustain Open Source With Us
item.dc:creator: Chad Whitacre
item.content:encoded:
Gratipay is co-organizing the first SustainOSS conference, to be held at GitHub in San Francisco on June 19. Weâ€™re aiming for â€œa one-day conversation for open source software sustainers,â€ a term coined recently by Justin Dorfman to describe people who care deeply about the health of the open source ecosystem.

The organizers want the event to be participatory without running afoul of the tyranny of structurelessness, so we invited a highly regarded facilitator, Allen â€œGunnerâ€ Gunn, to guide us. Gunner has asked participants to start thinking about the narratives we see this event fitting within, and the outcomes weâ€™d like toÂ achieve.

For my part, I see two narrative arcs to locate this day within, two ongoing cultureÂ shifts:

  1. Evolution of empathy in the firm. Open source projects create a value vacuum because they give the value first, and then accept payment. This is flipped from the dominant exchange model, where payment precedes value, but it differs from charity because there is a direct value exchange. Making this work requires us to evolve empathy in the firm. Fortunately, developing the capacity to properly value open source suppliers fits into a broader trend pointed to by certified B Corporations like Etsy, and Public Benefit Corporations (PBCs) like Kickstarter. Companies can value more than short-term profit.
  2. Evolution of open organizations. When open source projects adopt an economic identity, they become open organizations. This merging of open source with businessâ€Šâ€”â€Šnot open source as a commons that other businesses harvest from, but open source projects as themselves a first-class economic entityâ€Šâ€”â€Šrequires a new kind of leadership combining both open source and business/startup sensibilities. The Linux Foundation is leading the way among flagship projects, while Webpack shows promise for smaller projects. Platform cooperativism suggests some interesting directions here asÂ well.

The immediate outcome Iâ€™d like to see from Sustain is a community and shared identity around the issue of open source sustainability. Docs geeks have Write the Docs. Maintainers have Maintainerati. Now sustainers will have Sustain. The larger outcome will be for this new-found community to keep evolving open organizations, and evolving empathy in closedÂ ones.

Gratipay is excited to participate in Sustain, because these outcomes serve our own mission, to cultivate an economy of gratitude, generosity, and love. Register now to join us in June, and find us in #sustain on the Changelog Slack to collaborate in organizing theÂ event.

item.title: Seven Ways to Crowdfund Your Open Source Project
item.dc:creator: Chad Whitacre
item.content:encoded:
When Gratipay launched four years ago (we were called Gittip then), recurring crowdfundingâ€Šâ€”â€Šregular donations with a social elementâ€Šâ€”â€Šdid not exist. Today, there are a number of crowdfunding options, recurrent and otherwise, with several focused specifically on open source. In this post weâ€™re going to take a look at the options. Hopefully it inspires you to make a go of it with your own open sourceÂ project!

Letâ€™s start with four recurring crowdfunding platforms focused specifically on open source. They all offer the same basic features and are all about the same size. What differentiates one from another at this point is a) price, and b) openness.

Gratipayâ€Šâ€”â€ŠThe original (thatâ€™s us!Â :-). We donâ€™t take a cut of payments. Instead, we are funded pay-what-you-want on our own platform, just like the other open source projects on our platform. Furthermore, we practice open hiring and take-what-you-want compensation, so we are truly an open organization. ğŸ’ƒ

Liberapayâ€Šâ€”â€ŠLiberapay is a fork of Gratipay. They use the euro instead of the dollar, so they can be better for projects inÂ â€¦ Europe!Â ;-) They aspire to free speech and non-censorship. Like Gratipay, they are funded and distribute revenue on their own platform.

Bountysource Saltâ€Šâ€”â€ŠAs the name implies, Bountysource worked the issue bounty angle for years, before releasing their monthly recurring product Salt last year. They are a for-profit that takes a 10% cut, and have unfortunately run out of runway. The product is chugging along, but donâ€™t expect to get paid to work onÂ it.

Open Collectiveâ€Šâ€”â€ŠThe newest platform on the block, Open Collective has some smart folks behind it. As with Bountysource, they are a VC-backed for-profit company that takes a 10% cut. They also practice traditional hiring and compensation, which means that Open Collective isnâ€™t actually open enough for you to workÂ on.

Those are the going concerns that are focused on open source. But there are three other more general options that bear mentioning.

Patreonâ€Šâ€”â€ŠYouTube celeb Jack Conte teamed up with Stanford pal and serial entrepreneur Sam Yam to bring recurring crowdfunding to the consumer market. They focus on YouTube celebs (surprise!Â ;-) and other artists and digital content creators, but they can also be used for open source projects.

Kickstarterâ€Šâ€”â€ŠGeneral purpose crowdfunding sites can be used to fund open source projects. As of this writing, Font Awesome 5 is about to hit $750,000, making them the â€œmost backed software Kickstarter everâ€!

Stripeâ€Šâ€”â€ŠOf course, you can always roll your own social donations platform using lower-level payment processors. Django is a greatÂ example.

The bottom line is that there are lots of amazing tools available to help you build a sustainable funding base for your open source project. At Gratipay, we think what weâ€™re witnessing is open source projects evolving into fully-fledged open organizationsâ€Šâ€”â€Šand weâ€™re thrilled to be a part of the story. Whichever route you take, youâ€™ll be creating more opportunity to work together in the open, which is good news for all of us. GoodÂ luck!

Chad Whitacre is the founder of Gratipay. Thanks to Matt BK, Kwesi Aguillera, and Justin Dorfman for reviewing thisÂ post.
